III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS & CONCLUSIONS
A. Physical Description of Facility
This facility is located in the Wayne County Criminal Justice Center Complex. The
complex houses not only the Juvenile Detention (JD) but court rooms, court
offices and adult detention. The detention building has the Juveniles separated by
sight and sound from the adult inmates. There is a separate entrance for the JD
on the northeast side of the complex. This facility has 166 beds but is set up to
house 120 youth.
The entrance to the JD leads into a lobby where staff and visitors go through a
bag check and body scanner. The lobby also houses a reception desk and lockers
for staff and visitors to utilize. The rest of the first floor includes hearing rooms,
visitation rooms, administrative offices, a sallyport, kitchen, training room,
conference rooms, storage, laundry, master control, intake pod, Pod’s 1A, 1B, 1C,
and 1D.
Pod 1A opens into an open area to the right and straight ahead are 8 bedrooms.
To the left of the entrance is a classroom, staff desk, gym and another open area
with 8 more bedrooms straight ahead and to the right. The classrooms and the
gym are separated by walls made of windows. The glass in the windows is made
of corrections grade material. The Pod also includes 2 showers, a staff bathroom
2

and a counseling room. From the staff desk staff can see all areas of the pod
including into the classroom and gym. Intake pod has a desk in the middle of the
pod and 8 bedrooms on 3 sides of the room. Pod’s 1B and 1C are male
orientation pods. These pods each have six rooms and a staff desk. Pod 1D is the
female orientation pod. This pod has 4 bedrooms and a staff desk. Master control
opens into a vestibule that leads to a second door. The second door cannot be
opened until the first door is closed. There are 4 large monitors that monitor the
facility’s 800 cameras. This area will be manned by 2 staff at all times.
The second-floor houses Pods 2A, 2B, 2C, 2D and the medical unit. Pod 2A is
divided into 2 sides each with 8 bedrooms. The sides are divided by a glass wall
and door. On the right side of the pod is a hallway that leads to a classroom and a
gym. By the gym is a staff desk. The gym and classroom are both enclosed by
glass walls. The left side of the pod can access the classroom and gym from the
hallway at the front of the pod. The left side of the pod is also equipped with a
staff desk. There are 8 rooms and a shower on each side of the pod. The medical
unit is divided into 2 sides with a dental exam room and nurses’ station in the
middle. There are exam rooms, a waiting room, medication storage and offices in
the medical unit. There are also 2 close watch pods; one with 4 rooms and one
with 2. These 2 pods each have a shower room and an open area for recreation.
These pods each have a window that leads to a small control room for staff to
monitor the pods. It is also an expectation that a staff person will be inside the pod
with the youth. Pod 2B and 2C are set up the same as Pod 1A. Pod 2D is divided
into 2 sections. Upon entering the pod is a common area with chairs. There is a
gym in the corner on the left. On the right is a door and a glass wall that leads to
the other side of the pod which houses the bedrooms and shower rooms.
The third-floor houses Pods 3A, 3B, 3C, and 3D. It also houses a large gym,
multipurpose room, educational services, workout room, and music studio. All the
pods on this floor are set up the same as Pod 1A. The multipurpose area is a
large room with tables, cupboards for arts and crafts, and bookshelves for a
library. The room can be divided by a moveable wall.
All bedrooms throughout the facility are equipped with toilet, sink and bed. Some
bedrooms have affixed desk and stool or just affixed counters. There are ADA
compliant rooms on each pod.
The facility has an outdoor space that is in a courtyard. The outdoor space has a
concrete floor and walls on all sides. Three of the four walls are the height of the
building, and the third wall is about 1/3 of the other four walls in height. Each wall
has shallow horizontal grooves cut into the concrete. To prevent escape the
facility plans to install mesh to prevent youth from scaling the walls. Currently the
outdoor space is empty, but there are plans to install turf and recreation
equipment.
3

B. Program Description
The purpose of this program is to provide a short term, physically restrictive, safe,
secure and humane environment for youth detained by the Michigan Third Judicial
Circuit Court-Family Division. The JD accepts youth from age 12 to 17 years old.
The facility utilizes a token economy with a level system, individual contracting, a
youth peer group process model, a social living skills program, daily activity
structuring and a comprehensive educational system. Each youth develops
individualized behavior contract goals. Incentives, in the form of tokens and
privileges are provided to the youth for meeting behavioral expectations. Youth
who fail to meet behavior expectations fail to earn tokens and a higher level with
more privileges.
The facility’s medical and mental health services are overseen by in house
medical and clinical directors. The services include psychiatry, counseling,
medical care, dental care and 24-hour nursing staff.
The facility also provides opportunities for youth to visit with their parents, receive
mail, and make phone calls. As well as participate in religious services.
This facility is staffed 24 hours a day by fully trained awake staff. Staff are trained
in verbal de-escalation, crisis management, physical restraints, mechanical
restraints, token economy, cultural competency, SOGIE (Sexual Orientation,
Gender Identity Expression), and many others. The approved restraint model
utilized to train staff in physical restraints is Handle With Care. Juvenile Detention
Specialists (JDS) provide direct care to the youth with a minimum ratio of one staff
to ten youth for daytime hours and one staff to twenty youth during nighttime
hours.
This facility was previously licensed under license number CE820414010. All
corrective action plans implemented under this previous license were/will be
incorporated into the new facility’s policies and procedures to ensure the facility
continues to maintain compliance with those corrective actions and licensing
rules. The facility has agreed to complete policy revisions and obtain final
approval by the Division of Child Welfare Licensing within two weeks of being
issued the original license.
C. Rule/Statutory Violations
The facility is not in compliance with:
CCI Rule 400.4136 (2) Recreational activities, equipment, and supplies;
swimming restriction. (2) Residents shall be provided a variety of indoor and
outdoor recreational activities designed to meet the resident’s needs.
4

The facility has requested and received approval of a variance to not utilize
outdoor recreation until their outdoor space is ready to be utilized. As indicated
above the facility plans to install mesh to ensure the youth cannot escape over the
walls, turf over the concrete floor, and recreation equipment for the youth to
utilize.
Technical Assistance
Technical Assistance was provided in the following areas:
• Reference letters are to be dated and signed.
• Obtain official copies of degrees or transcripts
• Supervisors who are not qualified must be moved into a different role until
qualification can be reached.
Consultation
Consultation was provided in the following areas:
• Verify references if receiving a letter
• The new hire spreadsheet should include the staff’s name, date of hire, date
Handle with Care completed, 16 hours of orientation, and the date they
started working with the youth
IV. RECOMMENDATION
The facility submitted an application requesting to be licensed for 160 youth ages
9 to 17. The department is recommending that the facility be issued a six-month
original license for 120 youth ages 12 to 17.
